author | salary = | spouse ={{marriage|Karen Backfisch|1988}} {{marriage|Lisa Cadette Detwiler|2015}} | children = 2 | website = | footnotes = }} [[File:Jim Cramer on the Paris Agreement, Hewlett Packard Enterprise and more.webm|{{largethumb}}|Jim Cramer on the Paris Agreement and Hewlett Packard Enterprise]] '''James J. Cramer''' (born February 10, 1955) is an American television personality, former [[hedge fund]] manager, and best-selling author. Cramer is the host of [[CNBC]]'s ''[[Mad Money]]'' and a co-founder of [[TheStreet]], Inc. {{TOC limit|3}} == Early life == Cramer was born in 1955 in [[Wyndmoor, Pennsylvania]] (a suburb of [[Philadelphia]]),{{cite web|accessdate=June 6, 2009|title=Cramer, James J. (Jim) |url=http://www.pabook.libraries.psu.edu/palitmap/bios/Cramer__Jim.html |author=Michael A. Kowalski|date=Spring 2008|publisher=[http://www.pabook.libraries.psu.edu/ The Pennsylvania Center for the Book]}} to [[Jews|Jewish]] parents.{{cite web |author=israel says: |url=http://livingjewish.net/2010/05/06/jim-cramer-visits-israel/ |title=Jim Cramer Visits Israel |publisher=Living Jewish |date=2010-05-06 |accessdate=2012-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120710185612/http://livingjewish.net/2010/05/06/jim-cramer-visits-israel/ |archivedate=2012-07-10 |df= }} Cramer's mother, Louise A. Cramer, was an artist. Cramer's father, N. Ken Cramer, owned International Packaging Products in Philadelphia; the company sold wrapping paper, boxes and bags to retailers and restaurants. In one of his first jobs, he sold ice cream at [[Veterans Stadium]] during [[Philadelphia Phillies]] games.{{cite news|title=Jim Cramer |url=http://www.internationalspeakers.com/speaker/395/jim_cramer |publisher=[http://www.internationalspeakers.com/ International Speakers Bureau] |accessdate=June 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012192241/http://www.internationalspeakers.com/speaker/395/jim_cramer |archivedate=October 12, 2008 }} Cramer went to [[Springfield Township High School]] in [[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Montgomery County]]. He lives in [[Summit, New Jersey]].Staff. [http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/05_44/b3957001.htm "The Mad Man Of Wall Street: Jim Cramer wants to make you a lot of money. He's got plenty himself, so why does he bother?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213230149/http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/05_44/b3957001.htm |date=2008-02-13 }}, ''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]'', October 31, 2005. Accessed February 18, 2011. == Education == In 1977, Cramer graduated ''[[magna cum laude]]'' from [[Harvard College]] with a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[government]].December 23, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://today.law.harvard.edu/school-to-host-broadcast-of-mad-money-featuring-graduate-jim-cramer/| title= ''School to host broadcast of 'Mad Money' featuring graduate Jim Cramer'' ''Harvard Law Today'' |accessdate= Dec 18, 2016}} Cramer began his involvement with journalism in college, where he was the President and Editor-in-Chief of ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''. In 1984, Cramer received his [[Juris Doctor]] degree from [[Harvard Law School]]. == Career == === Early career as reporter === After graduating from Harvard, Cramer worked in several entry-level reporting jobs. Dating back to March 1, 1978, Cramer worked for the ''[[Tallahassee Democrat]]'' in [[Tallahassee]], [[Florida]], where he covered the [[Ted Bundy]] murders. Then-executive editor, [[Richard Oppel]], has said "[Cramer] was like a driving ram. He was great at getting the story." He subsequently wrote for the ''[[Los Angeles Herald-Examiner]]''. During this time, his apartment was robbed on multiple occasions, eventually losing all of his possessions and forcing him to live out of his car for several months.{{cite news|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|title=Crazy, Like a Fox|author=Kevin Cahillane|date=November 6, 2005|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/06/nyregion/nyregionspecial2/06njPERSON.html?pagewanted=print&_r=0}} He also worked for [[Governor of California|Governor]] [[Jerry Brown]]. Cramer was one of the first reporters at ''[[American Lawyer]]''.{{cite news|publisher=The New York Times|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DE3D71E3AF937A15750C0A96F948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=print|title=At the Bar | first=David | last=Margolick | accessdate=May 6, 2010 | date=March 24, 1989}} During his years at Harvard Law School, Cramer worked as a research assistant for [[Alan Dershowitz]]. He assisted Dershowitz's [[Sunny von Bülow#Appeal|campaign to acquit]] alleged murderer [[Claus von Bülow]] despite the fact that Cramer believed von Bülow was "supremely guilty." {{cite book|first=Jim|last=Cramer|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|isbn=978-0-7432-2489-5|year=2005|page=27|title=Jim Cramer's Real Money: Sane Investing in an Insane World}} Cramer was admitted to the New York Bar in 1985 but his license to practice law was suspended on April 2, 2009 for failure to pay the registration fee.{{cite web|url=http://www.nycourts.gov/reporter/3dseries/2009/2009_02525.htm |title=Matter of Attorneys in Violation of Judiciary Law \s 468-a|publisher=Iapps.courts.state.ny.us |accessdate=June 2, 2016}} === Investing === Cramer started investing in the stock market during his time at law school. Cramer began promoting his holdings by leaving stock picks on his answering machine. This impressed ''[[The New Republic]]'' owner [[Martin Peretz]], who gave him $500,000 to invest. In two years, Cramer made $150,000 for Peretz. Cramer's track record helped him obtain employment in 1984 as a [[stockbroker]] with [[Goldman Sachs]]' [[Private Wealth Management]] [https://www.loc.gov/bookfest/2006/authors/cramer.html Jim Cramer biography], Library of Congress. division. Cramer's success in this position led him to found his own hedge fund, Cramer & Co. (later Cramer, Berkowitz & Co.), in 1987. The fund operated out of the offices of hedge fund pioneer [[Michael Steinhardt]]'s Steinhardt, Fine, Berkowitz & Co. and early investors included [[Eliot Spitzer]] (a Harvard classmate, one of his oldest friends and former Governor of New York who resigned),Celizic, Mike. Todayshow.com, 12 March 2008, "[http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/23591111/ Jim Cramer on pal Spitzer: ‘Eliot screwed up’]." Retrieved 20 April 2010. Brill, and Peretz.{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/usnews/biztech/articles/070218/26eecramer_2.htm |title=Money & Business: Meet CNBC's Mad Money Man – US News and World Report |publisher=Usnews.com |date=August 30, 2007 |accessdate=April 27, 2010}} During Cramer's tenure with the fund from 1988 to 2000, he had one year of negative returns in 1998. The following year, the fund returned 47% and in 2000 28%, beating the [[S&P 500]] by 38 percentage points. Cramer retired from his hedge fund in 2001, finishing with a 24% average annual return over 14 years and having "routinely [taken] home $10 million a year and more." The fund was taken over by his former partner Jeff Berkowitz after Cramer's retirement. During that time, he was also an "editor at large" for ''[[SmartMoney]]'' magazine and was accused of unethically combining his investing and reporting activities when he bought stocks that he recommended just before his recommendation article came out, contributing to a $2 million personal gain.Laurence Zuckerman, [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/02/20/business/smart-money-rethinks-conflict-rule.html "Smart Money Rethinks Conflict Rule"]. ''New York Times'', February 20, 1995. Today, Cramer is barred by CNBC from trading stocks with his personal funds although he makes picks and sells his recommendations. In 1996 Cramer co-founded TheStreet, Inc. [formerly TheStreet.com, Inc.] with ''The New Republic'' editor Martin Peretz, one of his hedge fund's original clients. Cramer is currently a market commentator and adviser to the TheStreet, Inc. and is its second-largest shareholder. Cramer also manages a [[charitable trust]] stock portfolio which is tied to TheStreet, Inc. through a paid subscription service called Action Alerts ''PLUS'' Portfolio."[http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/05_44/b3957001.htm The Mad Man Of Wall Street] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213230149/http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/05_44/b3957001.htm |date=2008-02-13 }}" ''BusinessWeek'', October 31, 2005. Cramer owns a 10 per cent stake in TheStreet, the market value of which peaked at $1.7 billion but by 2014, the Nasdaq-listed company was worth less than $80 million.{{cite web|author=Financial Times |url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/99f24d20-7b40-11e4-87d4-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3Kwn5XyoE |title=Activist urges Cramer to sell TheStreet |publisher=Financial Times |subscription=yes |date=2014-12-04 |accessdate=2014-12-04}} Cramer claimed to be worth $50 to $100 million in October 2005. In 2009, Cramer received earnings of $461,276 from TheStreet, Inc.Apr 15, 2010. {{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1080056/000114420410020662/v181279_def14a.htm | title= ''Online Copy of US SEC Schedule 14A Proxy Statement for TheStreet.com, Inc.'' sec.gov |accessdate= Dec 18, 2016}} As of 2010, Cramer was the chairman of the board of TheStreet.com, Inc. === Career with CNBC === {{Main|Mad Money}} The cable television program ''Mad Money with Jim Cramer'' first aired on [[CNBC]] in 2005. According to CNBC's Web site in an article titled, "Mad Money Manifesto" by Jim Cramer, the show's mission statement and Cramer's job:
... is not to tell you what to think but to teach you how to think about the market like a pro. This show is not about picking stocks. It's not about giving you tips that will make you money overnight – tips are for waiters. Our mission is educational, to teach you how to analyze stocks and the market through the prism of events.
To provide [[Do-it-yourself investing|DIY investors]] and other viewers with "the knowledge and the tools that will empower you to be a better investor," ''Mad Money'' features many segments, including: The ''Lightning Round'', ''Game Plan'', ''Execution Decision'', ''Off the Charts'', ''Sell Block'', ''Market Marshmallows'', ''Outrage of the Day'', ''Mad Bull Disease'', ''Am I Diversified'', and ''Mad Mail''.{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/17283246/ |title=About Mad Money |author=Jim Cramer |publisher=CNBC}} After being a frequent guest commentator on CNBC in the late 1990s, Cramer co-hosted CNBC shows ''[[America Now]]'' and ''[[Kudlow & Cramer]]'' with [[Lawrence Kudlow]] in the early 2000s. Cramer hosted a one-hour radio show, ''Jim Cramer's Real Money'', until December 2006. "Take the Money and Run" by the [[Steve Miller Band]] was the intro to each of his radio shows. The show was similar to his ''Mad Money'' TV show. He also guest-hosted in the slot caused by the cancellation of ''[[Imus in the Morning]]'' ([[MSNBC]] and [[WFAN]]/[[Westwood One (1976–2011)|Westwood One]]) in May 2007. On November 13, 2005, [[Dan Rather]] did a sit-down interview with Cramer on ''[[60 Minutes]]''. Among the topics of discussion were Cramer's past at his hedge fund; for example, his violent temper and what finally led him to come to his senses and "calm down."{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} Footage of Cramer at his family home with his daughters and wife was also included.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} On November 15, 2005, Cramer mentioned on his program that he received hundreds of e-mails after his ''60 Minutes'' interview. This report was taped before Cramer's radio show, ''Smart Money with Jim Cramer'' moved to WOR and became syndicated under the CBS Radio banner. In 2005, Cramer appeared as himself in two episodes of the television series ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]''. He appeared to first announce that he had upgraded [[Bluth Company]] stock to a "Don't Buy" from a "Triple Sell," and then to say that the stock was not a "Don't Buy" anymore, but a "Risky." Cramer has also made appearances on NBC's ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today]]'', ''[[NBC Nightly News]]'', ''[[Live with Regis and Kelly]]'', [[ESPN Classic]]'s ''[[Cheap Seats (TV series)|Cheap Seats]]'', [[NBC]]'s ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]'', ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'', ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' and [[NBC]]'s ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. Season 7)|The Apprentice]]'' called "The Celebrity Apprentice." Cramer also appeared in the 2008 motion picture ''[[Iron Man (2008 film)|Iron Man]]'' spoofing Stark Industries on his show ''Mad Money'',{{cite news |author= Carlo Dellaverson |title=Cramer In 'Iron Man' |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/24427046/ |publisher=CNBC |date= May 2, 2008|accessdate=May 2, 2008}} and appears in the movie ''[[Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps]]''.https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/08/movies/08stone.html?bl&ex=1252555200&en=ba7f1af0b1943951&ei=5087 He also claims to have consulted for the original ''[[Wall Street (1987 film)|Wall Street]]'' movie by telling the filmmakers how he would get through to [[Gordon Gekko]].Cramer, Jim (2002).Confessions of a Street Addict. Simon & Schuster. p. 33. {{ISBN|978-0-7432-2488-8}}. On March 12, 2009, [[Jon Stewart]] interviewed Cramer on ''[[The Daily Show]]'' and challenged Cramer's recommendations of [[Bear Stearns]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/thu-march-12-2009/jim-cramer-extended-interview-pt--3|title=March 12, 2009 - Jim Cramer|work=The Daily Show}} On November 3, 2009, Cramer appeared on ''[[Martha (TV series)|The Martha Stewart Show]]'' to promote his new book ''Getting Back to Even''. Cramer stated that it was a great time to invest in real estate {{citation needed|reason=Citation for his appearance on the show|date=March 2015}} and that he had recently purchased the DeBary Inn in [[Summit, New Jersey]].{{Cite news| url = http://www.nj.com/news/local/index.ssf/2010/02/summit_investors_revive_histor.html|title= Summit investors revive historic inn|publisher=[[NJ.com]] |date =February 14, 2010}} ==Action Alerts charitable trust== In the timeframe of 2002 until May 2009 the performance of Cramer's charitable trust ''"Action Alerts PLUS"'' outpaced the [[S&P 500]] and the [[Russell 2000]]; while the charitable trust accumulated a return of 31.75%, the S&P 500 had a return of 18.75% and the Russell 2000 had a return of 22.51%. On an annual basis, the trust outperformed the S&P 500 by 7.35% and the Russell 2000 Index by 3.33%. Paul Bolster explains that Cramer beats the market in part because of the excess risk in his picks. "If we adjust for his market risk, we come up with an excess return that is essentially zero", Bolster said, adding that "zero", in this case, means his returns are roughly in line with the risk he's taking on.{{cite news|last=Phillips |first=Matt |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/marketbeat/2009/05/20/do-jim-cramer-stock-picks-beat-the-market-finance-profs-investigate/ |title=Do Jim Cramer Stock Picks Beat the Market? Finance Profs Investigate – MarketBeat – WSJ |publisher=Blogs.wsj.com |date=May 20, 2009 |accessdate=April 27, 2010}} Another criticism of Actions Alerts Plus is that it does not compare itself to indexes that include dividend reinvestment (as the SEC requires for stock-oriented mutual funds). According to a Kiplinger's article "One recent [Action Alerts PLUS] and included a chart, under the headline "Action Alert PLUS is CRUSHING the S&P 500," showing that the picks returned about 39% from the portfolio's inception through last March 31, compared with 15.5% for the S&P 500 over the same nine-year, three-month period. But the S&P figure did not include reinvested dividends. With them, the S&P 500 returned 38.3%."{{cite web|url=http://www.kiplinger.com/article/investing/T052-C018-S001-cramer-s-murky-math.html |title=Cramer's Murky Math |publisher=kiplinger.com |accessdate=January 5, 2015}} A study done by Wharton researchers Jonathan Hartley and Matthew Olson found that in the timeframe of August 2001 to March 2016, Cramer's charitable trust underperformed the [[S&P 500]] primarily as a result of underexposure to market returns in years after the 2008 financial crisis. As of March 31, 2016, Cramer's trust since inception had a cumulative return of 64.5% where the S&P 500 fewer dividends returned 70% during the same time frame. Wharton finance professor Robert Stambaugh said he didn't think the findings showed significant underperformance or outperformance when adjusting for a variety of factors, but did state "It's a commendable attempt to dig more deeply into the style that underlies Cramer's stock picks." {{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/jim-cramer-doesnt-beat-the-market-2016-05-13 |title=Jim Cramer doesn't beat the market |publisher=MarketWatch.com |accessdate=May 19, 2016}} CNBC does not permit Cramer to buy or sell any security he has spoken about on CNBC for the trust for five days following the broadcast. Whenever Cramer is acting within his portfolio or important news about his stocks occur, he sends out e-mails to his paying subscribers on TheStreet, Inc. Whenever mentioning a stock that he holds in his portfolio, he is required to disclose that he owns shares of such company on his CNBC show.{{cite web |url=http://www.brokersense.com/articles/jim-cramer-kramer-realmoney-com-vs-action-alerts-plus-rev-shark-feuerstein/ |title=RealMoney.com vs. Action Alerts Plus – Which One is Better? |publisher=Brokersense.com |accessdate=April 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120721231518/http://www.brokersense.com/articles/jim-cramer-kramer-realmoney-com-vs-action-alerts-plus-rev-shark-feuerstein/ |archivedate=July 21, 2012 |df= }} ==Selected controversies== ===Fox News Channel lawsuit=== In 2000 Cramer settled a lawsuit with [[Fox News Channel]] in which Fox had claimed Cramer reneged on a deal to produce a show for them. Their conflict began when Fox complained that Cramer promoted TheStreet, Inc's stock on the air.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/perfi/funds/0022.htm |title=Jim Cramer Quits Hedge Fund |agency=Associated Press |publisher=USA Today |date=December 4, 2000}} ===Market manipulation=== In March 2007, a December 2006 interview from TheStreet, Inc's "Wall Street Confidential" webcast stirred controversy after it appeared on [[YouTube.com]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PfC0mE9eVb4|title=Jim Cramer manipulation, insider trading, hedge fund scum|author=TheStreet.com TV; YouTube|year=2007}} In the video, Cramer described activities used by hedge fund managers to manipulate stock prices—some of debatable legality and others illegal. He described how he could push stocks higher or lower with as little as $5 million in capital when he was running his hedge fund. Cramer said, "A lot of times when I was [[short (finance)|short]] at my hedge fund ... When I was positioned short—meaning I needed it down—I would create a level of activity beforehand that could drive the [[futures contract|futures]]." He also encouraged hedge funds to engage in this type of activity because it is "a very quick way to make money." Cramer stated that everything he did was legal, but that illegal activity is common in the hedge fund industry as well. He also stated that some hedge fund managers spread false rumors to drive a stock down: "What's important when you are in that hedge-fund mode is to not do anything remotely truthful because the truth is so against your view, that it's important to create a new truth, to develop a fiction."{{cite news |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/jim-cramers-big-mouth-reveals/story.aspx?guid=%7BEFABFEB9%2D4FC7%2D45A8%2DA14A%2D6318372C33E2%7D |title=Jim Cramer's big mouth: His revelations only confirm what dupes average investors are |author=Thomas Kostigen |work=MarketWatch |date=March 23, 2007}} Cramer described a variety of tactics that hedge fund managers use to affect a stock's price. Cramer said that one strategy to keep a stock price down is to spread false rumors to reporters he described as "the Pisanis of the world." The comment was a reference to CNBC correspondent [[Bob Pisani]], who reports from the trading floor of the [[New York Stock Exchange]]. "You have to use these guys," said Cramer. He also discussed giving information to "the bozo reporter from ''The Wall Street Journal''" to get an article published.Boyd, Roddy "[http://www.nypost.com/seven/03202007/business/cramer_reveals_a_bit_too_much_business_roddy_boyd.htm Cramer Reveals a Bit Too Much] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070328172937/http://www.nypost.com/seven/03202007/business/cramer_reveals_a_bit_too_much_business_roddy_boyd.htm |date=2007-03-28 }}," ''[[New York Post]]'', March 20, 2007{{cite news |url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/03212007/business/cramers_big_mouth_business_roddy_boyd.htm |title=Cramer's Big Mouth: Clip Could Run Afoul of CNBC |author=Boyd, Roddy |work=New York Post |date=March 21, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225062909/http://www.nypost.com/seven/03212007/business/cramers_big_mouth_business_roddy_boyd.htm |archivedate=December 25, 2007 |df= }} Cramer said this practice, although illegal, is easy to do "because the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] doesn't understand it."{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/markets/2007-03-23-cramer-usat_N.htm |title=CNBC's Cramer boasts of manipulating markets |author=Matt Krantz|newspaper=USA Today |date=March 24, 2007}} During the interview Cramer referred to himself as a "banking-class hero."{{cite news|url=http://today.reuters.com/news/articleinvesting.aspx?view=CN&WTmodLOC=C3-News-2&symbol=TSCM.O&storyID=2007-03-20T225520Z_01_N20362926_RTRIDST_0_CRAMER-INTERVIEW.XML|title=Jim Cramer draws fire over manipulation comments|accessdate=March 20, 2007|last=Hamilton|first=Dane|date=March 20, 2007|work=Reuters|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070320180517/http://today.reuters.com/news/articleinvesting.aspx?view=CN|archivedate=March 20, 2007|df=}} ===SEC subpoena=== In February 2006, an investigation by the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) into allegations of collusion between short-sellers and a stock research firm led to the serving of subpoenas to TheStreet, Inc., and Cramer, as well as journalists for Dow Jones and Marketwatch.com. The SEC then began to back away from the subpoenas, indicating it had no intention of enforcing them after lawyers for Dow Jones said they would not comply. SEC Chairman [[Christopher Cox]] rebuked the SEC's staff attorneys for filing subpoenas on two Dow Jones reporters without first consulting him or the other top commissioners. Cox issued a statement saying neither he nor any of the SEC's four other commissioners were aware of the subpoenas, which he called "highly unusual."{{cite web |url = http://www.thestreet.com/_tscfoc/markets/marketfeatures/10270634.html |title = TheStreet.com, Cramer Get Subpoenas in Gradient Probe |author = Matthew Goldstein, TheStreet.com |date = February 27, 2006 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070509083152/http://www.thestreet.com/_tscfoc/markets/marketfeatures/10270634.html |archivedate = May 9, 2007 |df = }} The allegations had been raised publicly and in a lawsuit against Gradient by [[Overstock.com]] chief executive [[Patrick M. Byrne]]. In May 2007, it was revealed that the SEC had subpoenaed Byrne in May 2006, in connection with an investigation of the company.{{cite news |url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/05112007/business/company_byrne_d_on_probe_report_business_roddy_boyd.htm |title=Company Byrne-d on Probe Report |author=New York Post |date=May 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514042411/http://www.nypost.com/seven/05112007/business/company_byrne_d_on_probe_report_business_roddy_boyd.htm |archivedate=May 14, 2007 |df= }} ===Market performance=== Cramer is the founder, former owner, and former Senior Partner of Cramer Berkowitz, a hedge fund where Cramer reported a compounded annual "rate of return of 24% after all fees for 15 years" at Cramer Berkowitz. He retired from his hedge fund in 2001, where he finished with a self-reported 36% return in 2001.https://www.cnbc.com/id/15838187/ (These returns, however, cannot be independently verified, since hedge funds have no ticker symbols and are not regulated by the SEC. The only source should have been an independent client, who would have invested from day one.) On August 3, 2007, Cramer made a plea for Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke to cut interest rates supposedly because of comments he was getting from investment banks and their concern about adjustable-rate mortgage borrowers' increasing loan rates.{{cite news |title=Cramer's Rant, the Anniversary |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/15840232?video=808465173&play=1 |publisher=CNBC |author=Jim Cramer |date= July 29, 2008|accessdate=July 29, 2008}} On July 8, 2008, in an article in TheStreet.com entitled, "Look At The Facts," Cramer said, "The losses are increasing, the auction-rate preferreds are now biting, the mortgage implode-a-meter now measures how many home-builders are going under."{{cite news |title=Look at the Facts |url=http://www.thestreet.com/p/_search/rmoney/jimcramerblog/10432518.html |publisher=TheStreet |author=Jim Cramer |date=30 July 2008|accessdate=7 August 2008}} On "Hardball with Chris Matthews" for September 19, 2008, Cramer stated "It's not too late to be on the pom-pom ... the sideline" in regards to home teaser loans.{{cite news |title='Hardball with Chris Matthews' for September 19, 2008 |url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/26841599/ |publisher=MSNBC TV |author=Jim Cramer |date=September 19, 2008 |accessdate=September 19, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908100718/http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/26841599/ |archivedate=September 8, 2011 |df= }} Cramer spoke again on the Today Show on October 6, 2008, suggesting to investors, "Whatever money you need for the next five years, please take it out of the stock market."{{cite news |title=Jim Cramer: Time to get out of the stock market |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27045699/ |publisher=Today MSNBC |author=Michael Inbar |date= October 6, 2008|accessdate=October 6, 2008}} On September 22, 2008, ''Wall Street Journal'' bestselling author Eric Tyson, criticized Cramer's stock picks and his performance in general.{{cite web |url=http://www.erictyson.com/articles/20080922 |title=The Worth of Jim Cramer's Advice |accessdate=March 11, 2009}} An August 20, 2007 article in Barrons stated that within the select time frame of the previous two years, "his picks haven't beaten the market. Over the past two years, viewers holding Cramer's stocks would be up 12% while the Dow rose 22% and the S&P 500 16%."{{cite web|last=Alpert |first=Bill |url=http://online.barrons.com/article/SB118681265755995100.html |title=Shorting Cramer - Barrons.com |publisher=Online.barrons.com |date=August 20, 2007 |accessdate=April 27, 2010}} CNBC disputed the magazine's findings. In a February 9, 2009, story, Barrons further reported that betting against Cramer's Buy recommendations using options in the short term could yield 25% in the initial month.{{cite web|author=Bill Alpert|date=February 9, 2009|url=http://online.barrons.com/article/SB123397107399659271.html|title=Cramer's Star Outshines his Stock Picks}} ===Cramer's responses to criticism=== ====The White House==== On March 2, 2009, Cramer drew the attention of some critics after his evaluation of [[Barack Obama|President Obama]]'s spending plans and the administration's handling of the banking crisis. Cramer's name came up on March 3, 2009, during a [[White House]] press briefing after Cramer said that Obama was responsible for "the greatest wealth destruction I have seen by a president".{{cite news |title=Cramer to White House: Wealth Destruction Is Real |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/29490969/ |publisher=CNBC |date= March 3, 2009|accessdate=March 3, 2009}} An offended White House administration shot back,{{cite news |title=White House Knocks Jim Cramer For Calling Obama Budget "Greatest Wealth Destruction By a President" |url=http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/cnbc/white_house_knocks_jim_cramer_for_calling_obama_budget_greatest_wealth_destruction_by_a_president_110203.asp |publisher=CNBC |date=March 3, 2009 |accessdate=March 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305165325/http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/cnbc/white_house_knocks_jim_cramer_for_calling_obama_budget_greatest_wealth_destruction_by_a_president_110203.asp |archivedate=March 5, 2009 |df= }} with Press Secretary [[Robert Gibbs]] stating, "If you turn on a certain program, it's geared to a very small audience. I'm not entirely sure what he's pointing to make some of the statements." When pressed further by NBC's Tom Costello, Gibbs said, "You can go back and look at any number of statements he's made in the past about the economy and wonder where some of the back-ups for those are, too." On March 5, 2009, Cramer responded to the White House.{{cite news |title=Cramer: My Response To The White House |url=http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-my-response-white-house?page=2 |publisher=MainStreet |date=May 3, 2009 |accessdate=May 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309232629/http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-my-response-white-house?page=2 |archivedate=March 9, 2009 |df= }} He said, "Huh? Backup? Look at the incredible decline in the stock market, in all indices, since the inauguration of the president, with the drop accelerating when the budget plan came to light because of the massive fear and indecision the document sowed: Raising taxes on the eve of what could be a second [[Great Depression]], destroying the profits in healthcare companies, tinkering with the mortgage deduction at a time when U.S. house price depreciation is behind much of the world's morass and certainly the devastation affecting our banks, and pushing an aggressive cap and trade program that could raise the price of energy for millions of people." Cramer questioned criticism he received which he explained makes him "uncomfortable being in the crosshairs of columnists and comedians I enjoy."{{cite news |title=Cramer Takes on the White House, Frank Rich and Jon Stewart |url=http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-takes-white-house-frank-rich-and-jon-stewart |publisher=MainStreet |date=September 3, 2009 |accessdate=September 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819231729/http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-takes-white-house-frank-rich-and-jon-stewart |archivedate=August 19, 2009 |df= }} Cramer asked, "So, why after toiling in the cable wilderness for four years with ''Mad Money'' am I the target of the wrath of the Obama clan, and the darling, albeit surely momentary, of the Obama-critics? After all, my criticism of Obama's handling of the economic crisis is a lot less pointed than my withering August 2007 'They Know Nothing' meltdown{{cite news |title=Jim Cramer's famous rant about the "know nothing" Fed. |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/15840232?video=808465173&play=1 |publisher=NBC |date= July 29, 2007|accessdate=July 29, 2007}} against [[Ben Bernanke]]{{cite news |title=Cramer: Bernanke, Wake Up |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/15840232?video=452808336 |publisher=NBC |date= March 8, 2007|accessdate=March 8, 2007}} and the previous administration's handling of the economic crisis." ====Frank Rich==== Referring to March 8, 2009, charges leveled against Cramer by ''[[New York Times]]'' [[columnist]] [[Frank Rich]], Cramer said that he does not understand how Obama and his staff plan to raise taxes, institute cap-and-trade limitations and rework the health-care system all during a recession.{{cite news |title=No Respect: Cramer Criticizes His Critics |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/29601234 |publisher=CNBC |date= October 3, 2009|accessdate=October 3, 2009}} The article says: "It isn't that Cramer disagrees with Obama's vision for the country – he even agrees with taxing the rich – but now is not the time to put those plans into action. The president needs to solve our housing, employment and financial problems, and only then turn his attention to health care and changing the mortgage deduction." ====Bear Stearns recommendation==== On the March 11, 2008, episode of Cramer's show ''Mad Money'', a viewer named Peter submitted the question "Should I be worried about [[Bear Stearns]] in terms of [[liquidity]] and get my money out of there?" Cramer responded "No! No! No! Bear Stearns is not in trouble. If anything, they're more likely to be ''taken over''. Don't move your money from Bear."[https://www.cnbc.com/id/23575614 Mad Mail: Is Bear Stearns in Trouble?]{{cite news |title=Setting the Record Straight on Bear Stearns |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/29509036 |publisher=CNBC |date= March 4, 2009|accessdate=March 4, 2009}} On March 14, 2008, Bear Stearns stock fell 92% on news of a Fed bailout and $2/share takeover by JPMorgan.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/story?id=4516500&page=1|title=JPMorgan boosts offer for Bear Stearns to $10 a share|author=ABC News|work=ABC News}} On March 17, 2008, Cramer claimed his statements were made in regards to the liquidity of Bear Stearns brokerage accounts as opposed to Bear Stearns common stock.{{cite news |author= Tom Brennan |title=Cramer Was Right About Bear Stearns |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/23678693/ |publisher=CNBC |date= March 17, 2008|accessdate=March 17, 2008}} Cramer stated he was not recommending the common stock but allaying concerns about the account holder's liquidity held in a Bear Stearns brokerage account. Cramer later wrote about the incident: "I did tell an emailer that his deposit in his account at Bear Stearns was safe, but through a clever sound bite, (Jon) Stewart, and subsequently (Frank) Rich—neither of whom have bothered to listen to the context of the pulled quote—pass off the notion of account safety as an out-and-out buy recommendation. The absurdity astounds me. If you called Mad Money and asked me about Citigroup, I would tell you that the common stock might be worthless, but I would never tell you to pull your money out of the bank because I was worried about its solvency. Your money is safe in Citi as I said it was in Bear. The fact that I was right rankles me even more."{{cite web |last=Cramer |first=Jim |url=http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-takes-white-house-frank-rich-and-jon-stewart |title=Cramer Takes on the White House, Frank Rich and Jon Stewart | News | Money/Investing |publisher=Mainstreet |date=March 10, 2009 |accessdate=April 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819231729/http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-takes-white-house-frank-rich-and-jon-stewart |archivedate=August 19, 2009 |df= }} Michael Lewis, a journalist for the UK-based ''Evening Standard'', states that TheStreet.com listed Bear Stearns as a "Buy" at $62 per share on March 11, 2008, which was the same day as the caller's question and a day before the collapse of Bear Stearns.{{cite news |author= Michael Lewis |title=Bear Stearns proves bank CEOs don't have a clue |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard-business/article-23466011-details/Bear+Stearns+proves+bank+CEOs+don't+have+a+clue+about+credit+crunch+crisis/article.do |publisher=Evening Standard |date= March 27, 2008|accessdate=March 11, 2009}} However, TheStreet.com{{cite news|author=Stock Quote: BSC |title=TheStreet.com stock quote rating history |url=http://www.thestreet.com/quote/BSC.html |publisher=TheStreet.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427163000/http://www.thestreet.com/quote/BSC.html |archivedate=2009-04-27 |df= }}—the web site quote that shows the ratings history for actual changes that Cramer makes—indicates that Cramer changed Bear Stearns rating to a "Sell" on February 5, 2008. On [[Jon Stewart's 2009 controversy with CNBC|his March 12, 2009 appearance]] on ''[[The Daily Show]]'', Cramer admitted he made mistakes on his Bear Stearns calls.{{cite web|url=http://blog.indecisionforever.com/2009/03/13/jon-stewart-and-jim-cramer-the-extended-daily-show-interview/|title=Comedy Central Official Site - TV Show Full Episodes & Funny Video Clips|work=Comedy Central}} ====Jon Stewart==== {{Main|Jon Stewart's 2009 controversy with CNBC}} On March 12, 2009, Cramer appeared on ''The Daily Show with Jon Stewart''.{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/watch/thu-march-12-2009/jim-cramer-pt--1 |title=Daily Show interview of Jim Cramer |accessdate=March 14, 2009 |date=March 12, 2009 |work=The Daily Show with Jon Stewart |publisher=comedycentral.com}} Stewart reiterated earlier claims regarding the CNBC host's "silly and/or embarrassing and/or stupid financial observations."{{cite news |title=CNBC's Jim Cramer Responds to Jon Stewart's Response to CNBC's Jim Cramer |url=http://blog.indecisionforever.com/2009/03/10/cnbcs-jim-cramer-responds-to-jon-stewarts-response-to-cnbcs-jim-cramer/ |publisher=Comedy Central |date=March 10, 2009|accessdate=March 10, 2009}} Moreover, he claimed CNBC shirked its journalistic duty by believing corporate lies, rather than being an investigative "powerful tool of illumination."{{cite web |url=http://apnews.myway.com/article/20090313/D96T3SJ83.html |title=Stewart hammers Cramer on 'The Daily Show' |accessdate=March 13, 2009 |date=March 13, 2009 |publisher=My Way News}} For his part, Cramer disagreed with Stewart on a few points, but acknowledged that he could have done a better job foreseeing the economic collapse: "We all should have seen it more." {{cite web |url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/video/index.jhtml?videoId=221517&title=jim-cramer-unedited-interview|title=March 12, 2009: Jim Cramer Unedited Interview Pt. 2 |accessdate=March 12, 2009 |date=March 12, 2009 |publisher=Comedy Partners}} Stewart also discussed how short-selling was detrimental to the markets and investors. Cramer admitted to Stewart that short-selling was detrimental, stated his opposition to it, and claimed that he had never engaged in it, which contradicts earlier statements in which he described going short while managing a hedge fund. In a December 2006 interview from [[TheStreet.com]]'s "Wall Street Confidential" webcast Cramer said, "A lot of times when I was [[short (finance)|short]] at my hedge fund. ... When I was positioned short—meaning I needed it down—I would create a level of activity beforehand that could drive the [[futures contract|futures]]." He said, "I will say this: I am trying to expose this stuff, exactly what you guys do, and I've been trying to get the regulators to look at it."{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/27850397 |title=Out with Cox, in with Uptick Rule |accessdate=Nov 21, 2008 |date=Nov 21, 2008 |publisher=CNBC}} However, Stewart played several video clips from 2006 where Cramer discussed the spreading of false rumors to drive down stock prices and encouraged short-selling by hedge funds as a means to generate returns.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/investing/insights/blog/archives/2009/03/brawl_street_jo.html |title=Brawl Street: Jon Stewart vs. Jim Cramer |accessdate=March 13, 2009 |date=March 13, 2009 |work=Business Week}} At one point in a clip from December 22, 2006, he said, "I would encourage anyone in a hedge fund to do it." He called it a very quick way to make money and very satisfying. He continued, "By the way, no one else in the world would ever admit that, but I don't care, and again, I'm not gonna say it on TV." Stewart responded, "I want the Jim Cramer on CNBC to protect me from that Jim Cramer." Cramer again admitted that he can do better, and that he should try to change. The interview ended when Stewart pointedly suggested: "Maybe we can remove the 'financial expert' and the 'In Cramer We Trust' and start getting back to fundamentals on the reporting, as well, and I can go back to making fart noises and funny faces." Cramer responded: "I think we make that deal right here".{{cite web |url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/video/index.jhtml?videoId=221518&title=jim-cramer-unedited-interview|title=March 12, 2009: Jim Cramer Unedited Interview Pt. 3 |accessdate=March 12, 2009 |date=March 12, 2009 |publisher=Comedy Partners}} ====Response to pundits==== "The pundits," Cramer explained on March 9, 2009, in a MainStreet article, "who haven't paid attention to anything I have been saying or writing for the past 18 months are all over me."{{cite news|title=Pundits Attack Cramer, But Don't Pay Attention To Facts |url=http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-takes-white-house-frank-rich-and-jon-stewart?page=4 |publisher=MainStreet |author=Jim Cramer |date=September 3, 2009 |accessdate=September 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601222826/http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-takes-white-house-frank-rich-and-jon-stewart?page=4 |archivedate=June 1, 2009 |df= }} Cramer said the pundits "won't engage in the merits of, say, favoring Tier 1 capital for the banks vs. common equity, or forbearing on the banks to work the situation out over time because the banks can be profitable if we have some patience. They just attack me."{{cite news |title=Why Do Pundits Attack Cramer? |url=http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-takes-white-house-frank-rich-and-jon-stewart?page=3 |publisher=MainStreet |author=Jim Cramer |date=September 3, 2009 |accessdate=September 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618013601/http://www.mainstreet.com/article/moneyinvesting/news/cramer-takes-white-house-frank-rich-and-jon-stewart?page=3 |archivedate=June 18, 2009 |df= }} Cramer suggested, "It's time to get serious. It's time to take the issue from the pundits and from the left and right, and put it where it belongs: serious non-ideological debate to put out the real firestorm, the collapse of the economy from Wall Street to Main Street and the ensuing Great Wealth Destruction for all." ====Federal Reserve Open Markets Committee==== Cramer appeared on CNBC on August 3, 2007{{cite web|title=Cramer: Bernanke, Wake Up|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rOVXh4xM-Ww|website=YouTube|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=22 October 2015}} and said of the Fed Committee, "They're nuts. They know nothing. This is a different kinda market. And the Fed is asleep."{{cite web|last1=Carney|first1=John|title=Jim Cramer Was Right—They Knew Nothing!|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/100392107|website=CNBC.com|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=22 October 2015}} When the transcript from the August 7, 2007 meeting of the Federal Reserve Open Markets Committee was subsequently released on August 28, 2007,{{cite web|title=FOMC: Transcripts and Other Historical Materials, 2007|url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomchistorical2007.htm|website=federalreserve.gov|publisher=Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System|accessdate=22 October 2015}} it showed that Cramer's comments elicited laughter from participants during a comment from Dennis Lockhart, president, and CEO of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta. "I believe that the correct policy posture is to let the markets work through the changes in risk appetite and pricing that are underway, but the market observations of one of my more strident conversational counterparts—and that is not Jim Cramer [laughter]—are worth sharing."{{cite web|title=Meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on August 7, 2007|url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/files/FOMC20070807meeting.pdf|publisher=Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System}} Continued economic decline in the months that followed{{cite web|last1=Cassidy|first1=John|title=Anatomy of a Meltdown Ben Bernanke and the financial crisis.|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2008/12/01/anatomy-of-a-meltdown|website=newyorker.com|publisher=Conde Nast|accessdate=22 October 2015}}—a period that would become known as the [[Great Recession]]—and the subsequent rebound in the stock market have left Cramer seemingly vindicated.{{cite news|last1=Weisenthal|first1=Joe|title=Jim Cramer Got The Ultimate Vindication This Week|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fed-transcripts-show-that-jim-cramers-they-know-nothing-rant-was-right-2013-1|accessdate=22 October 2015|publisher=Business Insider, Inc.|date=20 January 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Stevenson|first1=Abigail|title=Cramer: 2007 Fed rant—has anything really changed?|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/08/03/cramer-2007-fed-rant-has-anything-really-changed.html|website=CNBC.com|publisher=NBCUniversal|accessdate=22 October 2015}} ==Personal life== On April 18, 2015, Cramer married Lisa Detwiler in Brooklyn, New York.Mallozzi, Vincent M. Apr 19, 2015. {{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/19/fashion/weddings/19DetwilerCramer.html| title= ''Article: 'Booyah' at the End of This First Date - Jim Cramer Marries Lisa Detwiler.'' nytimes.com |accessdate= Dec 18, 2016}} She is a real estate broker, and is the General Manager of The Longshoreman, a Brooklyn Italian bistro/restaurant. Cramer has two children from his first marriage.https://www.thestreet.com/markets/jim-cramer-talks-the-birds-and-bees-of-finance-14797186 ==Bibliography== * ''Confessions of a Street Addict'' (2002) {{ISBN|0-7432-2487-6}} * ''You Got Screwed! Mária | alma_mater = School of Electrical Engineering at the [[Slovak University of Technology in Bratislava]] | religion = | party = [[Independent politician| Independent]] }} '''Ján Lunter''', (born 15 July 1951) is a Slovak entrepreneur, owner of a family food company{{cite news|last1=Sliz|first1=Martin|title=Má byť banskobystrickým Kiskom. Výrobca známych nátierok prezradil, prečo ide proti kotlebovcom|url=http://hnonline.sk/slovensko/894244-ako-uspeje-v-zupnych-volbach-vyrobca-znamych-natierok-prezradil-preco-chce-kandidovat-proti-kotlebovcom|accessdate=5 November 2017|work=hnonline.sk|agency=Hospodárske noviny|publisher=MAFRA Slovakia|issn = 1336-1996|date=19 January 2017|language=sk}} and, following the [[Slovak regional elections, 2017|November 2017 elections]], governor elect of the [[Banská Bystrica Region]].{{cite news|last1=Jancarikova|first1=Tatiana|title=Slovakia's far-right party, ruling leftists lose regional elections|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovakia-election-extremists/slovakias-far-right-party-ruling-leftists-lose-regional-elections-idUSKBN1D501P?il=0|accessdate=5 November 2017|work=Reuters|date=2017}}{{cite news|title=Jan Lunter Celebrates Victory, Likely Defeating Far-right Governor Kotleba {{!}} News Now|url=http://newsnow.tasr.sk/policy/jan-lunter-celebrates-victory-likely-defeating-far-right-governor-kotleba/|accessdate=5 November 2017|work=newsnow.tasr.sk|date=5 November 2017}} ==Biography== Lunter studied [[Cybernetics]] at the School of Electrical Engineering at the Slovak University of Technology in Bratislava. Following the [[velvet revolution|gentle revolution]], he started a firm producing computer software and hardware, called Proces, and later started a food processing company called Alfa-Bio. In 2016 Alfa-Bio produced 160 tons of [[tofu]] and 100 tons of spreads. ==Candidacy== Lunter announced plans to run for governor of the Banská Bystrica Region in January{{cite news|title=Pribúdajú kandidáti na župana Banskobystrického kraja|url=https://mynovohrad.sme.sk/c/20435316/pribudaju-kandidati-na-zupana-banskobystrickeho-kraja.html|accessdate=5 November 2017|work=mynovohrad.sme.sk|agency=SME|publisher=Petit Press|date=17 January 2017|language=sk}} and officially entered the race in April 2017.{{cite web|last1=Pataj|first1=Roman|title=V Banskej Bystrici chce byť županom Ján Lunter|url=https://www.aktuality.sk/clanok/460121/v-banskej-bystrici-chce-byt-zupanom-jan-lunter/|website=aktuality.sk|publisher=Ringier Axel Springer Slovakia|accessdate=5 November 2017|language=sk}} By the end of August, Lunter had gained the support of [[Peter Pellegrini]] of [[Direction - Social Democracy]],{{cite web|title=Luntera podpora Smeru-SD na šéfa kraja prekvapila, Mičev ide ďalej|url=http://www.teraz.sk/regiony/luntera-podpora-smeru-sd-micev/277071-clanok.html|website=TERAZ.sk|accessdate=5 November 2017|language=sk-SK|date=1 January 1970}} and later won support from [[Most–Híd]] and [[Progressive Slovakia]].{{cite web|last1=Vražda|first1=Daniel|title=Kotleba chce byť znovu županom, ohlásil svoju kandidatúru|url=https://dennikn.sk/867691/kotleba-chce-byt-znovu-zupanom-ohlasil-svoju-kandidaturu/|website=Denník N|accessdate=5 November 2017|language=sk-SK}} As candidates from other parties withdrew, many gave support to Lunter, including [[Martin Klus]], who withdrew on 3 October;{{cite web|last1=Vražda|first1=Daniel|title=Klus sa vzdáva a podporí Luntera, ostatní kandidáti nechcú zverejniť svoje prieskumy|url=https://dennikn.sk/898414/klus-sa-vzdava-kandidatury-vo-volbach-ostatni-kandidati-nechcu-zverejnit-svoje-prieskumy/|website=Denník N|accessdate=5 November 2017|language=sk-SK}} and [[Viliam Baňák]], who withdrew on 4 October.{{cite web|last1=Mikušovič|first1=Dušan|title=Mičev potvrdil, že sa vzdáva kandidatúry: Podporím Jána Luntera|url=https://dennikn.sk/901822/micev-potvrdil-ze-sa-vzdava-kandidatury-podporim-jana-luntera/|website=Denník N|accessdate=5 November 2017|language=sk-SK}} By November, Lunter had support of all parties excluding the far-right [[Kotleba - People's Party Our Slovakia]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lunter, Jan}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Slovak politicians]] [[Category:Slovak businesspeople]] {{Slovakia-politician-stub}}

2006–2007 (Interviewer) |}} '''Leticia Ann Bjork Passmore''',{{cite web|url=http://www.craveonline.com/girl/leticia-cline|title=LETICIA CLINE|work=craveonline.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.topix.com/forum/city/cave-city-ky/TTRER2IS1VBOJ1NTV|title=Cave City Girl on Beauty and the Geek|work=topix.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2684814/mediaindex?ref_=nm_mv_close|title=Leticia Cline Biography|work=imdb.com}} {{aka}} as '''Leticia Cline''' {{cite web|url=http://uk.askmen.com/celebs/women/models_400/416_leticia_cline.html|title=Leticia Cline|work=askmen.com}} (born October 1, 1978) is an American [[fashion model|model]]. She is best known as a former interviewer for [[TNA Wrestling]], [[Maxim Magazine]], the reality show [[Beauty and the Geek]] and her [[Playboy]] magazine appearance in July 2008.{{cite web|url=https://shabooty.com/leticia-cline-pictorial-playboy-sexy-girls-next-door-3d0c31432f3e#.l8w2s9vol|title=Leticia Cline Pictorial (Playboy Sexy Girls Next Door)|publisher=shabooty.com}} ==Early career== Leticia began modeling at the age of 14. She went on to appear in a number of American magazines and spent a year modeling in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]]. She then focused on her education, earning degrees in [[psychology]] and [[finance]] from the [[University of Kentucky]] in 2000 and eventually became a [[certified public accountant]]; she worked as an accountant for four years. She also married and had a son, but the marriage broke up soon after.{{cite web|url=http://www.askmen.com/women/models_400/416_leticia_cline.html|title=Celebrity Profiles: Leticia Cline|publisher=askmen.com}} Since 2014, Leticia Ann Cline is co-founder partner of [http://www.standardmotorcycleco.com/ Standard Motorcycle Co] in [[Orlando]], [[Florida]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.cicadawheels.com/moto-life/leticia-cline-my-life-on-two-wheels/|title=LETICIA CLINE- MY LIFE ON TWO WHEELS|publisher=cicadawheels.com}} In 2015, the couple was invited by "Gentleman´s Ride" to make the 2015 video of [[Distinguished Gentleman's Ride]] {{cite web|url=http://sideroist.com/2015/09/25/distinguished-gentleman-genteel-lady/|title=Distinguished Gentleman & Genteel Lady|publisher=sideroist.com}} (a charity event held upon the last Sunday in September in cities worldwide, to raise awareness and funds for prostate cancer research and men's mental health programs). ==Television== On October 23, 2006, [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] producer [[Jessie Ward]] recruited Cline to TNA as an interviewer, complementing [[Jeremy Borash]]. Cline made her television debut on the November 30, 2006 episode of ''[[TNA Impact!]]''. She took a break from TNA in the beginning of fall 2007 to concentrate on other projects. Her final appearance with TNA was on their first ever two-hour show. Cline was officially granted her release from TNA on November 25, 2007. Cline was a Beauty on the 2008 season of the [[reality show]] ''[[Beauty and the Geek]]'' (Season 5). On week 5 of ''B&G'', Matt Carter and Leticia won [[The Young and the Restless]] Soap Opera Challenge. They were eliminated in the series finale and got third place. Cline appeared on the [[Howard Stern]] reality television show [[The Howard Stern Show|Bowling Beauties]] in 2008, but lost in the third episode. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.leticiacline.com/ Official Website] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cline, Leticia}} [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Glasgow, Kentucky]] [[Category:Professional wrestling announcers]] [[Category:University of Kentucky alumni]] [[Category:Female models from Kentucky]] [[Category:Women in finance]] [[Category:Actresses from Kentucky]] {{US-actor-model-stub}}

[[File:Marcos Prado Troyjo.jpg|thumb|Marcos Prado Troyjo in 2017.]] '''Marcos Prado Troyjo''' is a [[Brazil]]ian political economist, entrepreneur, social scientist, diplomat and writer. He is Director of the BRICLab at [[Columbia University]], a Forum on Brazil, Russia, India and China he co-founded with Christian Deseglise. He teaches at Columbia University's SIPA (School of International and Public Affairs) and is a Faculty Associate of Columbia's Center on Global Economic Governance (CGEG). He founded and directed the Center for Business Diplomacy, an independent think-tank on education, business and global affairs. Troyjo is also Director of the Intelligent Tech & Trade Initiative (ITTI) under the auspices of the International Chamber of Commerce. He holds a PhD in sociology of international relations from the University of São Paulo and did postdoctoral studies at Columbia. An economist and political scientist, Troyjo is an alumnus of The Rio Branco Institute (Instituto Rio Branco), the graduate school of international relations and diplomatic academy of Brazil's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
He is an op-ed columnist for ''[[Folha de S.Paulo]]'', Brazil's biggest circulation newspaper, as well as for other media outlets in Brazil and around the world. He is also foreign affairs commentator for Jovem Pan, Brazil’s leading radio network. Troyjo writes extensively on foreign affairs, global trade, rising powers, globalization, Brazil's political and economic prospects and Brazilian foreign policy. He serves on the Advisory Board of numerous for profit as well as not-for-profit institutions. He is a career diplomat and was [[Press Secretary]] at the Brazilian [[diplomatic mission|Mission]] to the [[United Nations]] in [[New York City|New York]]. He was the Brazilian speaker on [[World Press Freedom Day]] at UN Headquarters in New York in 2000-2001.
Troyjo is a Visiting Professor at RANEPA, the Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration. He is an Advisory Board member of the World Economic Forum Project on Emerging Best Practices of Brazilian Globalizers. He joined the "Leadership for the 21st Century" Program at [[Harvard]]'s [[Kennedy School of Government]]. Troyjo has been chosen one of "The Outstanding Young Persons of the World - TOYP" along with HM Queen Rania of Jordan and robotics scientist Takanori Shibata by the [[Junior Chamber International]] during its 2004 World Congress held in [[Fukuoka, Fukuoka|Fukuoka, Japan]]. Troyjo was the winner of the "[[Latin America]] Fellowship-2005" awarded by the Rt. Hon [[Helen Clark]], former Prime Minister of [[New Zealand]], and the "Invited Foreign Leader" of Japan Economic Foundation in 2012. He is a Research Scholar at the ''Centre d`Études sur l`Actuel et le Quotidien'', Université Paris Descartes (Sorbonne) and a member of the International Schumpeter Society.
He is the author of such books as: ''Deglobalization: Chronicle of a Changing World'' (2016), ''Technology & Diplomacy: Challenges for International Scientific and Technological Cooperation'', ''Brazil: Competitiveness in the Global Marketplace'', ''Manifesto of Business Diplomacy'', ''Trading Nation: Power & Prosperity in the 21st Century'' (chosen by ''[[Americas Quarterly]]'' as one of the best new books on policy, economics and business in the hemisphere in 2007).
Troyjo has been a guest speaker at world-renowned institutions such as Harvard University, Yale University, University of Washington, Columbia University, MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), Cornell University, University of Chicago, Brandeis University, Tsinghua University (China), University of International Business and Economics (China), Fudan University (China), CFAU (China Foreign Affairs University), IE-Instituto de Empresa (Spain), New Economic School (Russia), IVA-The Royal Academy of Engineering Sciences (Sweden), ICRIER-Indian Council for Research on International Economic Relations (India), Hitotsubashi University (Japan), Keio University (Japan), Canon Institute of Global Studies (Japan), Bavarian State Ministry for Economic Affairs and Media, Energy and Technology (Germany), University of Auckland (New Zealand), Canning House (UK), Kedge Business School (France), Korean National Diplomatic Academy (South Korea), Seoul National University (South Korea) and the Council on Foreign Relations.
In 2018 he has been indicated by [[Paulo Guedes]], the future minister of finance of Brazil, as future secretary of international trade and foreign affairs in [[Jair Bolsonaro]]'s government.
